parse.title: UCL Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis

text.*:
The Centre for Advanced Spatial Analysis (CASA) is a research centre at University College London (UCL) which specialises in the application and visualisation of spatial analytic techniques and simulation models to cities and regions.

Contents

  • 1 History
  • 2 Research areas
  • 3 Research programme
  • 4 Contributions
  • 5 External links
  • 6 References

History[edit]

CASA was established in 1995 by a group of UCL academics who wanted a focus for their research across different academic departments in the field of geographic information systems (GIS). Michael Batty was appointed the first director and initially held a joint appointment as Professor of Spatial Analysis and Planning in the Departments of Geography and The Bartlett School of Planning. He is now Chairman of the Centre. In 2000, Paul Longley was appointed Deputy Director and Professor of Geographic Information Science. He now directs UCL's ESRC Consumer Data Research Centre (CDRC).[1] CASA is still largely funded through research grants but from 2010 it began to diversify, introducing Masters programmes in spatial analysis and in Smart Cities. Professor Andrew Hudson-Smith took over the directorship in 2011 and appointed a Deputy Director, Dr Adam Dennet, in 2016. The Masters courses developed since 2010 include the MSc in Smart Cities and Urban Analytics and the MRes in Data Science and Visualisation. It currently has 6 lecturers and 2 teaching fellows leading its courses. Sir Alan Wilson was appointed Professor of Urban and Regional Systems in 2008. The Centre is now an administrative unit in The Bartlett School which is the Faculty of the Built Environment.

Research areas[edit]

CASA researches the science of cities, working with city governments and related research groups on simulating and visualising urban problems. Their work on transport and movement has included Transport for London’s Oyster card data,[2] public bikes schemes such as the London's cycle hire scheme,[3] population segregation in large cities[4] as well as climate change in the London region.[5] The centre is active in exploring how the Internet of Things can be deployed in large urban areas linking objects in the built environment through internet technologies,[6] and was active with the Technology Strategy Board’s Future Cities Catapult in pioneering new software systems for smart cities such as dashboards and portals.[7] Its research programme in city science concentrates on applying social physics to urban systems based on modelling the diffusion of behaviours such as the 2011 London riots[8] and it is heavily involved in using methods of scaling and allometry to examine city performance.[9]

Research programme[edit]

CASA’s research programme is primarily funded by research grants from the British research councils, mainly ESRC and EPSRC. Since 2008, the centre has been increasingly funded by EU research grants from the 7th Framework and from the European Research Council (ERC) and in 2014, it was awarded funding from the Technology Strategy Board's Future Cities Catapult [10] to provide demonstration capabilities for urban and regional modelling.

CASA has graduated some 41 PhDs since 2000. Several alumni have made important contributions to the science of cities working in geographic information systems, spatial analysis and urban modelling at UC Berkeley, Maryland, George Mason, UCL, KRISH, LSE, TU-Istanbul, KCL, Cardiff, Tehran, Manchester, OU, ETH-Zurich, Kingston, Malta, Warwick, Birkbeck, and Liverpool. OpenStreetMap (OSM) originated in UCL CASA and The Bartlett, and the firms GeoFutures[11] and Intelligent Space (acquired by Atkins) were associated with the centre. The company Prospective Labs spun-off from CASA in 2016 and is engaged on developing new software systems for planning and land management.

Contributions[edit]

Members of CASA have pioneered the development of urban and regional modelling through a series of books that go back to the 1970s. Their work is published in a series of web sites on the CASA Blog Aggregator.[12] Key works that reflect CASA’s research programme are Fractal Cities (1994),[13] Cities and Complexity (2005),[14] The Science of Cities and Regions (2012),[15] Agent Based Model of Geographical Systems (2012),[16] and The New Science of Cities (2013).[17] The journals Environment and Planning B,[18] edited by Batty, and Future Internet,[19] edited by Hudson-Smith, are run from CASA. The major research focus of CASA is in blending the visualisation of complex urban systems with their simulation.

External links[edit]

  • CASA website
  • CASA Blog Aggregator

  2. ^ London’s Tube and big data: Underground movement The Economist 14 July 2012
  3. ^ Hussey, Matt, Boris-bike routes for a city with no Tube, Wired Magazine 2 March 2011 Archived 3 November 2014 at the Wayback Machine.
  4. ^ Pickford, James and Giles, Chris (2012), London: The world in a city, Financial Times, 23 July 2012
  5. ^ Centre extends science of planning, Planning Resource, 19 June 2009
  6. ^ Cookson, Clive (2011) ’Internet of things’ is set to come, Financial Times, 14 September 2011
  7. ^ Dean, Will (2012) Will Dean's Ideas Factory: Everything you wanted to know about your city, The Independent, 10 May 2012
  8. ^ Geere, Duncan (2012) Model suggests earlier response could have shortened London riots, Wired Magazine, 20 April 2012
  9. ^ The laws of the city, The Economist, 21 June 21, 2012
  10. ^ "Future Cities Catapult"
  11. ^ "GeoFutures"
  12. ^ "The CASA Blog Aggregator"
  13. ^ Michael Batty & Paul Longley (1994) Fractal Cities: A Geometry of Form and Function (Academic Press, San Diego, CA and London)
  14. ^ Michael Batty (2005) Cities and Complexity: Understanding Cities with Cellular Automata, Agent-Based Models, and Fractals (MIT Press, Cambridge MA and London)
  15. ^ The Science of Cities and Regions (2012)
